source.3474b042:
!mkdir wheels

!python -m pip uninstall -y tensorflow
!python -m pip uninstall -y tensorflow-gpu
!python -m pip uninstall -y keras

#!python -m pip download tensorflow==1.15.0 -d wheels/
!python -m pip download tensorflow-gpu==1.15.0 -d wheels/
!python -m pip download keras==2.2.4 -d wheels/
source.02e29e38:
!kaggle datasets init -p wheels/

%env dataset_title=xrrWheelsSet4

!sed -i -e "s/INSERT_TITLE_HERE/$dataset_title/g" -e "s/INSERT_SLUG_HERE/$dataset_title/g" wheels/dataset-metadata.json

!cat wheels/dataset-metadata.json
source.d907ce42: ### This notebook is used to package multiple python wheels as a kaggle dataset that you can then use to install packages when working in "No internet" mode. (Check also companion notebook: https://www.kaggle.com/xavierreyrobert/load-wheels-from-dataset-no-internet-pip-install)
source.b151126d:
## Credential setup

We will use Kaggle Apis. Check https://www.kaggle.com/docs/api about how to generate/use an API Token.

Then **import manually your kaggle.json as dataset** (+Add data). Default location should be credentials/kaggle.json

**Make Sure to keep it is private**
source.269e0e5d:
## Download all required wheels

Instead of installing the wheels we download them to wheels directory using pip.
source.37912e5a:
## Generate dataset metadata and metadata update

In order to upload our custom dataset to kaggle we need to create the associated metadata.

Update the dataset_title variable bellow with your dataset title
Here slug and title will be identical
source.74654cc9: ## Our custom dataset has been uploaded now check the companion notebook to understand how to deploy wheels from it. (https://www.kaggle.com/xavierreyrobert/load-wheels-from-dataset-no-internet-pip-install)
